title: In the Matter of Thomas E. Elliott, Jr.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL
VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT
AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court
  

 
   
     
      
        In the Matter of Thomas E. Elliott, Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-042
  Submitted May 13, 2004 - Filed August 2, 2004

DISMISSEDÂ Â 

 
   
     
      
        Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, 
          for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Thomas E. Elliott, Jr., of Columbia, pro se.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This disciplinary action arises from respondent 
  Thomas Elliottâ€™s representation of Mary Brown (Brown) in a case recently reviewed 
  on certiorari by this Court: Brown v. Zamias, Op. No. 2002-UP-715 (S.C. 
  Ct. App. filed November 15, 2002), certiorari dismissed as improvidently 
  granted, Op. No. 2004-MO-10 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed April 5, 2004).Â  The case 
  was a negligence action brought by Brown after she tripped and fell across an 
  extension cord on the floor of a Rock Hill mall.Â  
In this disciplinary matter, Brown alleges that 
  respondent failed to depose two potential deponents and conditioned his taking 
  of the depositions upon her prepaying the deposition costs.Â  The Subpanel for 
  the Commission on Lawyer Conduct (Subpanel) found that respondent did not commit 
  lawyer misconduct but recommended the issuance of a letter of caution.Â  We find 
  that the charges against respondent should be dismissed.Â  
Factual/Procedural Background 
Brown was injured when she tripped over an extension cord at a Rock Hill Mall 
  on Christmas Eve 1997.Â  Moments before Brown tripped, the Matthews, a couple 
  from Winston-Salem, had just walked over the cord, and Mrs. Matthews nearly 
  tripped over the cord.Â  Because they were only a few yards away, the Matthews 
  heard Brown fall, returned to where she had fallen, and told her that they would 
  be happy to provide testimony of the unsafe condition that the power cord had 
  created.
Brown hired respondent to represent her in a negligence action against the 
  mall.Â  She signed a retainer agreement, which established a 33.3% contingency 
  fee for respondent and provided:

  If, however, suit shall be required to obtain recovery, the client agrees 
    to pay litigation costs to initiate this action in the amount of N/A.

On August 22, 2000, the Matthews sent letters to 
  respondent describing the events of Christmas Eve 1997 and expressing their 
  willingness to further assist Brown in her attempt to receive â€œthe compensation 
  she deserves.â€Â  On August 28, 2000, in a letter to Brown, respondent wrote: 
  â€œI anticipate that I should try to make plans to go to Winston-Salem to take 
  [the Matthewsâ€™] depositions for presentation at court.Â  Obviously, it would 
  be an extreme inconvenience for them to travel to York County on short notice 
  to testify.â€Â  
During the course of respondentâ€™s preparation of 
  Brownâ€™s pending litigation, he incurred significant discovery expenses, including 
  those incurred from taking a video deposition of Brownâ€™s doctors in Columbia.Â  
  On various occasions, respondent asked Brown to pay for these pre-litigation 
  costs, and Brown either was unable to pay or refused to pay for these expenses.
Respondent told Brown that in order for him to travel to Winston-Salem to take 
  the Matthewsâ€™ depositions, Brown would have to pay the deposition expenses in 
  advance.Â  Brown did not prepay those discovery costs, and therefore respondent 
  did not take the depositions.Â  
After the Commissionâ€™s investigation into respondentâ€™s potential misconduct 
  began, respondent stated to the investigating attorney (ATA) that the primary 
  issue in dispute in Brownsâ€™s case was damages, as there was a question of whether 
  Brownâ€™s prior orthopedic problems contributed to the medical expenses she incurred 
  from falling on the mall floor.Â  Thus, in respondentâ€™s view, the Matthewsâ€™ testimony 
  -- that the cord was on the floor of the mall right before Brownâ€™s injury -- 
  would not have shed any light on the damages issue.
Brown also complained of (1) respondentâ€™s failure to keep her informed about 
  her case and (2) the abrupt nature in which respondent whisked her to the trial.Â  
  The case moved up the York County roster such that Brown did not find out when 
  her case was going to trial until the morning of her trial.Â  Respondent prepared 
  Brown for trial on the way from Columbia to Rock Hill, and the trial proceeded 
  that afternoon.Â  Brown prevailed, and, after the trial judge denied the mallâ€™s 
  motion for a directed verdict, the jury awarded $43,000 in damages but apportioned 
  fault 50%-50% between Brown and the mall.
The mall appealed, and the court of appeals reversed the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  
  The court of appeals found that as an invitee, Brown was owed only the duty 
  to be warned of a latent hazard.Â  And since Brown testified that â€œshe immediately 
  saw the cord and cover when she looked back after fallingâ€ and that â€œhad she 
  been looking down or watching where she was walking she would have seen the 
  cover and been able to avoid tripping,â€ the court ruled that the cord was an 
  open and obvious hazard, and thus no duty was breached.Â  Zamias, Op. 
  No. 2002-UP-715 at 3-5.Â Â  
After reviewing respondentâ€™s conduct in Brownâ€™s case, namely (1) respondentâ€™s 
  failure to depose the Matthews and demand that Brown pay for the depositions 
  in advance and (2) respondentâ€™s alleged mischaracterization to the ATA that 
  the primary issue in Brownâ€™s case was damages, [1]  the Subpanel determined that respondent did 
  not violate any Rules of Professional Conduct but determined that his 
  conduct warranted a letter of caution.Â  The full Panel of the Commission on 
  Lawyer Conduct adopted this finding.Â  
Law/Analysis
The Subpanel found that respondent did not violate Rules 1.1 (competent representation), 
  1.3 (diligence and promptness), and 1.4 (keeping the client reasonably informed) 
  of the Rules of Professional Conduct, 407, SCACR, for failing to depose 
  the Matthews because their testimony was not determinative on the issue of Brownâ€™s 
  damages or the issue of whether the mall was on notice of the hazardous condition.Â  
  We agree with the Subpanel and find that the Matthewsâ€™ depositions were not 
  essential to Brownâ€™s case. 
The Subpanel also found that respondent did not violate Rules 1.4 (keeping 
  the client reasonably informed) and 1.5 (charging reasonable fees) by demanding 
  that Brown prepay the deposition expenses.Â  The contingency fee agreement that 
  Brown signed contained an ambiguous provision concerning litigation fees that 
  stated that the amount Brown may have to pay in litigation costs was â€œN/A.â€Â  
  This ambiguous provision could have led Brown to conclude -- as she did -- that 
  she need not pay any pre-trial expenses.Â  
Since the inquiry into respondentâ€™s potential misconduct 
  began, respondent has omitted this provision from his standard retainer agreement.Â  
  We hold that respondentâ€™s decision to remove the litigation cost provision from 
  his retainer agreement represents the appropriate corrective action in this 
  matter.
Conclusion
Upon full review of the record in this matter, we find that the charges against 
  respondent should be DISMISSED.

   
     
     
      s/Jean H. Toal                                   
        Â  C.J.
        s/James E. Moore                             
        Â Â Â Â Â  J.
        s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           
        Â Â Â Â Â  J.
        s/E. C. Burnett, III                                
        Â Â Â Â Â  J.
        s/Costa M. Pleicones                        
        Â Â Â Â Â  J.
    
  





 
   
    [1]  Initially, the ATA believed that respondent deliberately misrepresented 
    that the only issue at trial was damages, but the Subpanelâ€™s report noted 
    that the ATA no longer believed that to be the case.

title: Gordon v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Spencer L. Gordon, 
          Respondent, 
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        State of South Carolina, 
          Petitioner. 
      
    
  



ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From York County
  Marc Westbrook, Trial Court 
  Judge
  Â John C. Hayes, III, Post-Conviction 
  Relief Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 
  2004-MO-044
  Submitted February 19, 2004 
  - Filed August 16, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Attorney General Henry D. 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Chief, Capital 
          and Collateral Litigation Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney 
          General David A. Spencer, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Assistant Appellate Defender 
          Tara S. Taggart; and Tara Dawn Shurling, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  Spencer 
  Gordon (respondent) was indicted for trafficking cocaine under S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 44-53-375 (c).Â  Respondent was found guilty of conspiracy of possession with 
  intent to distribute crack cocaine, and was sentenced to twenty-one years imprisonment 
  and a fine of $20,000.Â  Respondent appealed his conviction, which was affirmed 
  by the Court of Appeals.Â  State v. Gordon, Op. No. 99-UP-507 (S.C. Ct. 
  App. filed September 8, 1999).Â  
Respondent filed an application for 
  post-conviction relief (PCR), and moved for summary judgment on the grounds 
  that the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over his conviction.Â  
  The PCR judge granted respondentâ€™s motion.Â  The State filed a petition for writ 
  of certiorari, which was granted.Â  We reverse.Â  
ISSUE
Did the trial court have subject 
  matter jurisdiction to convict respondent of a violation of Â§ 44-53-375(b) as 
  a lesser-included offense of Â§ 44-53-375(c)?
ANALYSIS
In April 1997, respondent was indicted, 
  along with several others, for conspiracy to traffic in crack cocaine.Â  At a 
  subsequent proceeding, the State, on respondentâ€™s motion, was ordered to amend 
  the indictment to include more specificity with regard to the charge.Â  The amended 
  indictment, charging respondent with trafficking in crack cocaine in violation 
  of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(c), was true billed by the Grand Jury in May 1997. 
  Respondent was tried only on count one of the amended multi-count indictment.Â  
  This count read:
COUNT ONE
  TRAFFICKING IN CRACK COCAINE
  S.C. Code Ann. Section 44-53-375(c)

  That WILLIE E. GORDON, AKA â€œJRâ€, 
    SPENCER GORDON, RENEE LEACH, HARRY BARNETTE, CALVIN BARNETTE, ROSIE D. JONES, 
    AKA â€œPOM-POMâ€, TOMMY JAMES RHINEHART, FNU LNU, AKA â€œTâ€, JUAN REID, and other 
    persons both known and unknown to the Grand Jury, did Traffick [sic] in Crack 
    Cocaine in York County, from on or about May of 1995 until the date of this 
    indictment, by either knowingly conspiring to sell, or deliver, or 
    purchase, or bring into this State, or provide financial assistance or did 
    otherwise aid, abet, or attempt to sell, or deliver, or purchase, or bring 
    into this State four hundred grams or more of crack cocaine, a Schedule II 
    controlled substance under provisions of Section 44-53-110, et seq., 
    Code of Laws of South Carolina (1976), as amended, such conduct not having 
    been authorized by law and is a violation of Section 44-53-375(c)- Trafficking 
    in Crack Cocaine. (emphasis supplied).Â  

The jury was charged that conspiring 
  to possess crack cocaine with intent to distribute was a lesser-included offense 
  of trafficking in crack cocaine. Respondent was found guilty of conspiring to 
  possess crack cocaine with intent to distribute.Â  
At the PCR hearing, respondent moved 
  for summary judgment on the grounds that conspiring to possess with intent to 
  distribute crack cocaine is not a lesser-included offense of trafficking in 
  crack cocaine.Â  The PCR judge granted the motion stating, â€œit has long been 
  established that conspiracy is not a lesser-included offense of [the] substantive 
  offense which is the object of the conspiracy.â€ 
Generally, conspiracy is not a lesser-included 
  offense of a substantive offense.Â  State v. Ferguson, 221 S.C. 300, 70 
  S.E.2d 355 (1952); State v. Greuling, 257 S.C. 515, 186 S.E.2d 706 (1972); 
  State v. Steadman, 257 S.C. 528, 186 S.E.2d 712 (1972).Â  South Carolina 
  Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375 (c) (2002), which the indictment tracks, states â€œA person 
  who knowinglyâ€¦conspires to sell, manufacture, deliver, purchase or bring 
  into this Stateâ€¦ten grams or more ofâ€¦crack cocaineâ€¦is guilty of a felony which 
  is known as â€˜trafficking in ice, crank, or crack cocaine.â€™â€ (emphasis supplied). 
  As defined in this section, there is no distinction between conspiracy 
  to traffic and the substantive offense of trafficking in crack cocaine; 
  in other words, the statute incorporates conspiracy as one of a number of ways 
  the substantive offense may be committed.Â  See i.e. Harris 
  v. State, 349 S.C. 46, 562 S.E.2d 311 (2002) (holding that under Section 
  44-53-370 (e) the legislature clearly intended that conspiracy to traffic be 
  treated as trafficking).Â  One of the ways respondent was alleged to have trafficked 
  in crack cocaine was by conspiring to â€œsell, manufacture, deliver, purchase, 
  or bring into this Stateâ€¦â€ as permitted under the general statute of trafficking 
  in crack cocaine.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370 (2002).Â  Conspiracy to traffic 
  in crack cocaine is encompassed in the indictment under which respondent was 
  charged, as one way to traffic in crack cocaine.
An indictment confers jurisdiction 
  upon the circuit court and gives the defendant notice of the charges against 
  him.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§17-19-20 (1985); see State v. Owens, 293 
  S.C. 161, 359 S.E.2d 275 (1987).Â  The â€œcircuit court does not have subject matter 
  jurisdiction to convict a defendant of an offense unless there is an indictment 
  which sufficiently states the offense, the defendant waives presentment, or 
  the offense is a lesser included offense of the crime charged in the indictment.â€Â  
  State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 579, 564 S.E.2d 103, 105 (2002). Possession 
  with intent to distribute crack cocaine is a lesser-included offense of trafficking 
  in crack cocaine.Â  Matthews v. State, 300 S.C. 238, 387 S.E.2d 258 (1990).Â  
  Therefore, conspiring to possess crack cocaine with intent to distribute is 
  a lesser-included offense of conspiracy to traffic in crack cocaine.Â  See 
  e.g. State v. Gosnell, 341 S.C. 627, 535 S.E.2d 453 (Ct. App. 
  2000)(holding that conspiracy to traffic cocaine in the amount of 400 grams 
  or more can include conspiracy to traffic lesser amounts.) 
CONCLUSION
We REVERSE the PCR court, 
  as the circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to convict respondent of 
  conspiring to possess crack cocaine with intent to distribute as a lesser-included 
  offense of conspiring to traffic in crack cocaine, for which respondent was 
  indicted.Â  
TOAL, C.J., and MOORE, J., concur.Â  
  WALLER, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.Â  BURNETT, J., not participating.
JUSTICE WALLER:Â  I respectfully 
  dissent.Â  In my opinion, conspiracy to possess with intent to distribute 
  crack cocaine is not a lesser-included offense of trafficking crack cocaine.Â  
  Accordingly, there having been no indictment for conspiracy to PWID crack, the 
  trial court was without subject-matter jurisdiction to convict Gordon of this 
  offense; I would affirm the PCR courtâ€™s grant of relief.Â  
In a criminal case, the trial courtâ€™s 
  subject matter jurisdiction is limited to those crimes charged in the indictment 
  and all lesser-included offenses.Â  State v. Watson, 349 S.C. 372, 563 
  S.E.2d 336 (2002).Â  An offense is a lesser-included offense of another if â€œthe 
  greater of the two offenses includes all the elements of the lesser offense.â€Â  
  State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, ___, 589 S.E.2d 6, 8 (2003), citing 
  State v. Elliott, 346 S.C. 603, 606, 552 S.E.2d 727, 728 (2001).Â  A lesser 
  offense is included in the greater only if each of its elements is always 
  a necessary element of the greater offense.Â  Knox v. State, 340 S.C. 
  81, 530 S.E.2d 887 (2000); State v. Easler, 327 S.C. 121, 489 S.E.2d 
  617 (1997).Â  See also 42 C.J.S. Indictments and Informations Â§ 
  218 (1991)(an offense can be considered as lesser-included if, and only if, 
  all essential elements of the lesser offense are included among essential elements 
  of greater offense).Â  If, under any circumstances, a person can commit the greater 
  offense without being guilty of the purported lesser offense, then the latter 
  is not a lesser-included offense.Â Â  State v. LaCoste, 347 S.C. 153, 553 
  S.E.2d 464 (Ct. App. 2001), cert. dismissed as improv. granted 353 S.C. 
  538, 579 S.E.2d 318 (2003).Â Â  
Here, it is patent that conspiracy 
  is not an essential element of the greater offense of trafficking.Â  Although 
  conspiracy is one method by which trafficking may be achieved, it is not always 
  a necessary element of trafficking; there are numerous ways listed in the statute 
  via which a person may commit that offense (e.g. sell, manufacture, deliver, 
  purchase, bring into this state, provide financial assistance, or otherwise 
  aid or abet).Â  See State v. Easler (although felony DUI and ABHAN 
  may both involve element of â€œserious bodily injury,â€ there are other circumstances 
  which may give rise to ABHAN such that serious bodily injury is not a necessary 
  element of ABHAN; therefore, ABHAN is not a lesser-included offense of felony 
  DUI).Â  
I am not unmindful that this Court 
  has, on occasion, found an offense to be lesser-included notwithstanding a lack 
  of strict adherence to the elements test.Â  See State v. Elliott, 
  346 S.C. 603, 606, 552 S.E.2d 727, 728 (2001).Â Â  However, we have done so only 
  where, as in Elliott, the offense has traditionally been considered a 
  lesser-included offense of the greater offense charged.
Here, the majority recognizes that 
  conspiracy is not generally a lesser-included offense of a substantive offense, 
  nor has it traditionally been so considered.Â  As noted by Justice Toal in her 
  concurrence in State v. Wilson, 311 S.C. 382, 391, 429 S.E.2d 453, 458 
  (1993), conspiracy â€œis a completely separate offense from the substantive 
  offenses which are the objects of the conspiracy.â€Â  (emphasis supplied).Â  
  The majority correctly notes that possession with intent to distribute crack 
  cocaine is a lesser-included offense of trafficking.Â  Matthews v. State, 
  300 S.C. 238, 387 S.E.2d 258 (1990).Â  However, that PWID crack is a lesser-included 
  offense of trafficking is of no consequence.Â  The inquiry here is whether conspiracy 
  is a lesser-included offense of trafficking.Â  In my opinion, as demonstrated 
  above, it is not.
Accordingly, in my opinion, the trial 
  court was without subject-matter jurisdiction to convict Gordon of conspiracy 
  to possess with intent to distribute crack.Â  I would affirm the PCR courtâ€™s 
  grant of relief.Â

title: Mitchell v. State Democratic Party Executive Committee
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT

ANALYSIS
